comment_text:
If you're about to leave a comment saying that faster creatures aren't actually less efficient, read this first. I presented that part a bit strangely.

At 2:14, I say moving quickly is less efficient, giving the example of a creature moving a unit distance in half the time, using twice the energy. Then, at 4:53, I show a formula for the energy cost per unit time, which depends on the square of the creature's speed.

I gave distance per time, energy per time, and distance per energy at separate parts of the video, and that was confusing.

So here's a more explicit summary.
If we double a creature's speed...
- its distance per time is doubled (the definition of speed)
- its energy per time is quadrupled (because it depends on the square of speed)
- its distance per energy is halved: (2x distance per time) / (4x energy per unit time)

That last bullet is the "efficiency" from the video. With its starting energy for a day, a 2x-speed creature can only travel half the distance.

I’d like to present a theory on why speedy builds have triumphed, time and time again, in these simulations:


According to the rules, a blob will not survive a single day without eating; This implies that they are endothermic (or warm-blooded, in layman’s terms.)


Endothermic and Ectothermic both describe the thermal energy components of a living being;

• Endothermic creatures have their own, functioning heat source, which means that they often boast potent muscles and speed, at the cost of needing to refuel on a regular basis.

• Ectothermic, however, has little to no internal heat to speak of, as the creature instead relies on external sources to maintain warmth. Since their “engine” is weak and slow to process fuel, they can take advantage of this to become greatly efficient; One solid meal can last them for days or weeks. (A.K.A Cold-blooded)


Now, since the blobs are implied to be endothermic, they need to be able to get their quarry, right here, and right now. This is where speed wins out; There’s not much of a point to being efficient with your energy, when you risk being too late to snag your fill of the day.

The winning mutations got to where they are because they committed to their strengths, rather than trying to patch up their weaknesses.

In some context there is evolution towards superior creatures. An isolated stable unique biome will create "optimal" creature for that situation only and inferior to everywhere else. It might even lose its ability to mutate fast enough to adapt.
Creatues evolving in varied overlapping and changing biomes (seasons) and migrating species will be "tested" more and adapt to deal with many different situations. It can develop complex things (lungs or certain brains) that give a huge advantage in the situation it evolved in but is still kinda nice in others. That wouldn't have evolved without this side step. In the specific biome the tendency to mutate will just be a waste. But when perfected and readjusted these mutations might not even have a real cost to them or small cost with reasonable benefits.

The perfect example of evolution are dolphins and hippo's. The hippo may resemble a pig more, but is closely related to a dolphin! Some land based mammal readjusted to sea life by again evolving to a fish shaped dolphin-ancester creature. This water based mammal then again readjusted to land as a hippo swapping fins for legs!

And although a rough description of natural selection, not of much use.

This video forces an important question: what happens to a population when it begins to change its environment in a way that the population believes is better for itself?
In the sim, we learned that the environment controls everything from the number of a population to the traits of the population - the population changed according to the environment. What happens when that relationship shifts, and the population changes the environment to suit *it*? Will the environment still change the population, or will the population develop the appropriate environment to achieve a sort of stasis?

Very nice approach, super nice explanation, and a very nice way to explain it with simple graphics. But, sorry, this is the same s* who have been told for generations being stuck with an evolutionary theory based on the capitalistic dreams of an 18th century British economist. Here, like in 99% of the time, that evolution is explained, one important factor, which, luckily, has been demonstrated during the last 20 years to be even more important than how strong and handsome you are, is obviated: cooperation. Cooperation with both environment and your own species. Stronger groups have demonstrated to have higher survival rates than stronger lonely individuals, that at the end monopolize resources and ended up destroying them. Red Queen theory works pretty well with hunter-pray interactions for it ANIMALS. But what about plant-animal interactions, or even, soil-plant/animal interaction, which are the majority. In these cases, the mutation rate is very different (obviously non-existing for soil and other geological resources) and a very well adapted species can end up with a whole ecosystem in a matter of few years. Balance, integration in the ecosystem, interaction intra- and inter-species are factors that have been taking out of the equation for hundreds of years. Evolution happens in millions of years, not in one generation. Adaptation is not about how much you can monopolize a niche, but how long can u use that inch and how much can you optimize that niche exploration by cooperating with another species (in many cases from different kingdoms). Complex ecosystems are demonstrated to be wey more resilient than simple networks. Is not about competition, is about cooperation.

Those factors that I mentioned are the actual game-changing in evolution. Let's move to a new century and re-think the way we teach evolution. Being stuck with the same approach for 200 hundred years does not sound very scientific. This sounds difficult to digest nowadays since we are tough to compete with everything around us since we are born. Darwinism is nice, but just a tiny part of the equation.

Okay, paused at 4:07. That is NOT what the "selfish gene" means. When Richard Dawkins coined the term, he meant we can look at evolution from the point of view of the gene. One gene might be shared by every member of the group. From the point of view of the gene, it is only important that the gene survives, meaning the group must survive. Individual creatures don't matter. Thus, the selfish gene as actually a evolutionary explanation for altruism and self sacrifice, literally the opposite of what must people assume. Turns out he didn't coin the best term.

Well this is strange, I made a very similar simulation to this. They were green little blobs that I called "sludge monsters" and they ate green dots of food. It took place on a grid. I was messing around with agent based modeling. I allowed them to breed with each other and gave them traits to fight, breed or "help" each other by giving them some of their energy. While messing around with it at one point it would always collapse into this system where a huge swarm of sludge monsters crawled across the map, most with very short lifespans. I had created a kind of macro organism where they would just breed immediately and die. I hadn't taken into account the fact that energy was being introduced into the system during a "birth" so a sludge monster would be born with full energy that didn't come from its parents.

For breeding and mutation I didnt know a great algorithm, so I just had a blending of thr parents traits with a random chance of mutation, and if mutation occurred I would grab a new value for the trait from a normal distribution with a reasonable standard deviation for the range of values

I think natural selection involves some kind of chaos going on. Take the last case for example, maybe a part of the reasons why speed gets to be important is that the group (the competitors) is getting faster (therefore the slower ones are having disadvantages automatically. )

To those trying to equate natural selection to evolution; that's still not how DNA works.
You cannot GAIN new information to increase the complexity of your creatures because this process simply SELECTS from genetic information that was already present.
So just remember why it's called natural selection; because it's simply selecting from the traits that were already pre-existing.

The synthesis of all the required proteins needed in the history of life via the mutation lottery is preposterous. Some rare beneficial mutations...sure.... no one takes issue with micro-evolution or survival of the fittest. But macro-evolution? ... I'm afraid not. You don't have a mechanism that is even remotely feasible Random copying errors of the .DNA will not deliver the hyper precise coding necessary for the seemingly endless variety of functional protein shapes, let alone organs, body plans, and staggering diversity of life, because they are, of all things, random.
Natural selection doesn't "select" anything. It is bereft of consciousness. It is just another term for survival of the fittest....the result of a gargantuan crapshoot.... pretty rarefied territory. Do you think that will take you from a forelimb to a wing? Absurdity squared. A bird in flight makes our most advanced aircraft [all intelligently designed] look like clunky, lumbering toys that simply go fast. How about bats developing sonar?... I guess they hit the jackpot. Proponents of the theory have have imbued natural selection and copying errors with magical powers in order to make the theory work The gradualism of the origin of species is not mirrored in the fossil record. This caused Darwin much concern. We are still faced with the conundrum of sudden appearance of species and stasis vs. small incremental steps. There's a lot of speculation about "links" but no chains and no threads.
The genesis of all life resides in precision information. The mutation lottery is utterly and unceasingly both imprecise and unreliable. Stay healthy everyone. Health is wealth.

A few problems with this simulation, it lacked realism when using a very short amount of time to determine death and made the primary survival goal to also relate to the primary reproduction rate.

In reality this is not the case. In reality it's a 3 or 4 pronged system (food, breeding, negative health effects, and averaging) eating food does not guarantee breeding, you still need to partner up, while eating food does increase the chances of negative health effects; so for creatures which eat more than thier fair share it should increase thier death rate by decreasing lifespan. Meanwhile also in relation to food, you need to consider that creatures can actually live substantial amounts of time without food in real life and still recover from it, that does not always decrease lifespan, in fact some say it might increase it in some instances where the lack of food does not happen over long periods or frequently.

then you need to isolate genders, and add priorities "food or mating?". if you ran that simulation you'd find that those with the best and brightest traits end up struggling to survive and those with negative or average traits tend to just hang around and breed and eat occassionally. Meaning the population steadily decreases in quality but increases in number meanwhile truely "advanced" beings are a rare occurrence and while they carry on they end up breeding with a creature with worse traits at which thier traits are averaged.

There is only one direction; Down. welcome to devolution. that is "de-evolution". one look at people and nature and you find that there are very rarely any truely superior specimins in any way shape and form and the traits of the majority of the population are actually generally not the best choices, they were just the most available choices that were not preoccupied with bettering themselves and then these offspring stunt the progress made by the best by forcing their offspring to be dumbed down by the massive swaths of inferior creatures. the whole "natural selection always chooses the best" is a load of feces. I mean imagine there is one really best creature what are the chances it can find a mate who is also in a similar state of awesomness? if not, sucks to be your kids just a little worse every generation.

NATURAL SELECTION is comatose. No hindsight, no foresight, and no goal. It is wholly dependent on an undirected process.... a slave if you will. It doesn't "select" anything. It's a descriptive term for the process leading to survival of the fittest. The result of accidents. The mutation lottery is utterly and unceasingly unreliable. The notion that together these provide a mechanism that can code the DNA with the instructions for the assembly of every uniquely shaped protein required in the history of life is nonsensical. Try writing an intelligible book via an alphabet lottery. Now how about the book of life? You need a mechanism that possesses a reasonable degree of both creative power and reliability.... if it is to drive, that is, life towards ever increasing complexity... consistently... over eons of time... from bacteria to Beethoven It must buck the tide of randomness. And it is a relentless tide. Proponents of the theory have, out of necessity, imbued natural selection with truly fantastical powers just to suit a worldview.. The proposed mechanism does not manifest where these never before seen but vital protein shapes come from or why they come at all. Their assembly requires the utmost in precision and new information The number of possible combinations of amino acids at each peptide bond in even a relatively short protein chain of 150 amino acids easily eclipses human comprehension....it inflates exponentially. in an explosive manner. But if you need hemoglobin you better be absolutely dead on target with the information supplied by the DNA or the protein will not fold into the required shape, This newly acquired information is supposedly brought about by random damage or mutations. Natural selection is impotent in this scenario.{where's a friend when you need one?}
. Random copying errors are... ready for this? ...random. . This antiquated theory belongs to the 19th century where a single cell was thought to be scarcely more complex than a blob of Jell-O And let's not forget we need organs, body plans and staggering diversity. To buy into this wheezing fairytale, one must check reason and logic at the door. Count me out.
Did I mention the Cambrian Explosion?...in reality a mega-explosion of hyper- precise information. Reminds me of an old Dracula movie. Think of it as a stake in the heart of the theory. For adherents to the theory speculation and assumption are the tools of the trade... and have little gravitas. You don't have a feasible mechanism. Never did. Precious young minds deserve better. You made a slight error. You mis considered concentration of food on map ! When food decreased , the map size didnot decrease , so the food conc. Decreased. This is what gave sudden advantage to sense and speed over size. But in a high food density map you dont need sight baby because there is food where ever you land especially if you were large and can consider smaller over populated friends as food also. In this scenario you need size much and you wont even need sight because all the map is food ! Sight and sensation only pays off if the target is very small and lowly concentrated. But if the target is all over the place then sensation would be a luxury and size would be vital for survivability because you are crowded with large sized preditators so you have no place to escape to unless you are large as them or you will probably end up as their food. No place to escape. All are large and the map is filled with them due to high food conc. So if you change food amount change map size also. And by the way. They all died when the conc decreased all of a sudden because they were all blind fat and slow. The low conc env. Favors sight and they were blind. So they didnot have time to evolve sight and speed so they died out of blindness mainly. Given enough time they became sensing , agile and slim. This tells us if conditions are good and food abundant you grow weak fat slow and blind. If you are stressed and challenged you will have to adapt or you will die out of weakness even if there is still some food to support a portion of previous total population.

Here are some blob builds I made up:
Tank (prioritizes size over speed)
Uses its size to scare away high sense, low size blobs, meaning it can forage with no competition.

Grab-and-go (prioritizes sense and speed) Once it sees food it uses its high speed to grab it before anyone else

Speedster (speed over all)
Randomly runs in, nabbing all the food. If it sees a predator (which is kinda hard) it runs away.

Gas Guzzler (highest base stat total)
It uses its high stats to hunt and forage without competition. It gets so much food that it doesn’t care about it’s high energy cost

THIS VIDEO is totally irrelevant. Neo-Darwinism is nothing more then a worldview... and we are, and have been living in, the Dark Age of science for too many decades now. It is high time we put the 19th century in the rear view mirror. It is also disgraceful this antiquated theory is still being taught as fact to precious young minds. The fossil record simply does not support it... a great concern for Darwin.. Natural selection is a nice sounding term but it is nothing more than a slave to a random process. It possesses no hind sight, no foresight, and it has no goal. It is in a permanent coma. A creature either survives or it doesn't. No one, BTW, takes issue with micro-evolution. A beneficial mutation is very rare. and it is the result of a crapshoot. Mere chance. A longshot. Supporters of the theory want you to believe that if you add enough crapshoots together you will get the body plans of every creature that ever lived. Reams and reams of hyper-precise coding that never exited before. The coding for new, never before seen, vital function proteins, via the mutation lottery, is, as Spock might say, not rational. The demands are far, far, too great. The odds of success way, way too small. How do you get from a forelimb to a wing?... just sustain random damage to millions of pieces of DNA over a long period of time and the all powerful OZ.... "natural selection".... gets really smart. A bird in flight makes our most advanced aircraft look like clunky, lumbering toys..
There are other thorny problems such as; sudden appearance of species in the fossil record, stasis, the Cambrian Explosion, metamorphosis, irreducible complexity, the selection of only left handed amino acids in production of proteins, highly specified and functional protein shapes from out of thin air. Untold numbers of them. Then there's the mind-boggling transition from water to land and subsequently from land to air in small increments, and to adherents of the theory the ever present need to reduce the complexity of life to that of a cartoon or a bicycle. In the real world it is a massively challenging and ever receding horizon for researchers. It is all about precision information and where it comes from. I unequivocally reject the idea that its genesis resides in random copying errors of the DNA. Absurdity squared. Furthermore, the mutation lottery is utterly and unceasingly unreliable. Any feasible mechanism must possess some degree of reliability in order to drive life into ever increasing complexity from bacteria to humans over eons of time.
Neo-Darwinism is, in the simplest of terms...preposterous. I couldn't care less how many people support the theory. The indoctrination has been going on now for what seems like an eternity.
Whatever it once was, the theory has devolved into an entity whose primary function is to supersede the need for intelligence in the ubiquitous design we actually observe. The "blind watchmaker", however, remains unemployed because...of all things... he's blind And so is natural selection. Whatever your beliefs may be... an atheist ,a creationist or anything in between.. this is not science. It is an agenda. It is a worldview. I'm for getting back to science These aren't the droids your looking for.... move along.

I believe you literally showed the effects of an apocalypse situation or a famine situation, as you showed the effects of, "the quickest reaction survives". As in, those that could see the farthest or had the most sense, and who also had the ability to get there quickly, survive the most. We actually see this with the dinosaurs, as large and imposing as the gigantic creatures were, smaller animals and such survived extinction instead of them after they all died, because they had the senses and speed to survive. Because of the lack of food, (apocalypse/crisis situation) slower contestants couldnt travel far enough to survive getting food, and without the amount of sense neccessary to even find "prey" to eat, the larger beings ran out of lives to continue with and died. However, even fast beings died because they didnt have enough sense to find food at a distance, so they ran in fast little circles until they died, wasting their time searching for food in their small circle of influence. So, your theory was right, most creatures near the middle of the simulation become sense based creatures, with gigantic circles of influence. But from there creatures needed to reach the food first, so by the end of the simulation we had only ten or so species of extremely quick, extremely sense based creatures, who lived the longest. A world where larger creatures would thrive is a smaller plane, where finding smaller beings to eat would guaranty survival and the large creatures could find them in the tighter space, not risking too much movement. You said it your self, the energy price of finding that next meal is really the nail in the coffin for larger species, which is why they are so uncommon today compared to small reptiles or mammals, and why the only kind of insects we have now, are the small kind. I think you're incorrect about speed being less effecient. In your model, speed is exactly as efficient because you're using 2/1 energy in 1/2 time but also covering 2/1 space. So it's taking the same amount of energy to cover the same amount of space, but with the benefit of speed and no overall cost. In real life, it takes more than twice the energy to move your body at twice the speed, which is why people can walk farther than they can jog, can jog farther than they can sprint.

So maybe it could've been 2.5/energy for 2/1 speed (or something like that) to get a closer to accurate model.

This is where from a philosophy of science becomes quite interesting. Evolution is defined as an undirected process. This simulation is actually directed by rules, the rules determine the outcomes. What is interesting is that there was nothing about the rules regarding the food, you assume from the video the food was always in the same place, what cannot be calculated is a chance/proximity factor based on previous causality. So you may have a mutation for more speed but if the previous generation creates the next generation at a location further away from the food then the non speed mutation gets favoured. The rules in the simulation are actually an example of intelligent design. You have the intelligence from the human being to create a rule set that allows speed as a mutational advantage. As soon as you change the rules and atributues you get different outcomes.

Good video on natural selection, BUT, the thing is, natural selection is removing traits from a populus, not adding.  Once a trait is completely selected/bred out of the populus it cannot be mutated back in.  It must be reintroduced from outside the populus.    It's why animal's are going extinct.  Traits are gone that they need for adaptation.  Mutations are caused by a degradation of the genome.  Birth defects are mutations....  natural selection works against mutations, not in conjunction.

08:40 Speed being favorable is not surprising to me. With low food supply and high sense, several creatures will sense the same food spot and go straight for it. Only the fastest runner will get it and survive. Others will have lost time and energy in the race. They will only survive if they still have enough energy and speed to reach another food spot before other creatures. So the equilibrium is with enough sense to ensure a good chance of finding food, enough speed to reach that food and enough energy left to get back home and occasionally divert to a secondary food spot when a faster creature gets the first one.

I think the fast creatures appeared because even though being fast is less efficient, if there's one fast creature with many slow creatures, the fast one can easily outpace the slow ones, get food that's closeby, and return to its home. Then it reproduces, introducing more fast creatures, and the cycle continues. They grow exponentially and eventually become less efficient, but better against slow creatures.


Edit: I think if the food were more spaced out, being slow would be valued over being fast, as they'd waste less energy than their fast counterparts and be able to travel long distances with a relatively low amount of energy.

from this simulation from a true natural selection standpoint is that in this simulation the creatures eat each other or try to consume each other in a free for all, as if they're cannibalizing each other. A couple of points:


1. One of the things I noticed was the random placement of food items. In nature, a pear (for example) grows on a pear tree, and it's highly unlikely that that pear tree is going to move anywhere... even over the course of several generations in fact. And so this little sim was a bit more random than what takes place in nature (I'm talking about this particular context only, of course - other food items such as small mammals might in fact be spread around more randomly). A clever addition, imo, would have been to include at least two different food types - static types (which perhaps have around 0.25 Energy) and non-static types (which, although harder to find, provide our blobby friends with around 1 Energy).


2. Whilst it was fun to see the addition (and the effects) of speed, size and sense, another trait which I feel would have been helpful to the blobbies is inherited memory. This would help each new generation blessed with a good memory stat locate a static food type (mentioned above) more easily and in a more focussed way over their speedy, sizeable, sense-enhanced 'rivals'.


Would have been interesting to see how things panned out with those two additions.


Anyway, fun vid to watch. Thanks for sharing :)

Is there any kind of speciation in this simulation, or are all organisms able to interbreed? If it's the latter, it may explain why speed increased in the first example where speed was the only parameter, but not in the second. When speed is the only parameter there is a general drift towards the optimal speed value ( there is essentially one way of making a good living in this world). When multiple parameters can be tweaked, there are pressures driving drifts in opposing directions (you can make a good living being big, or being small). When all organisms can interbreed, the split can never happen and the organisms hover around a mid point. Unless you did indeed add speciation, and then I'm just talking shit :P

Another interesting discovery was made here; if the environment changes rapidly, the odds of extinction go up. It's not that there wasn't room for a population in the lower food environment, or that the population couldn't optimize for the lower food environment, but that the change was too drastic and there wasn't time to adjust before extinction occurred. That, I think, is the real danger of rapid human-caused climate change; the environment changes so quickly that there is insufficient time for populations to adjust and extinction is the result. That is why even though certain regions are made more "hospitable" (areas in the arctic circle get warmer on average, more rain falls in some arid areas, etc) extinctions still occur.

The reason why sense has a high amount of variance is because there are tradeoffs.  Having a high amount of sense is great for big creatures because it means they can see the smaller creatures, but having too much sense when you're small and slow means wasting your time running from things that are going to kill you, and running from things that perhaps aren't a threat. This may sound stupid but maybe it's worth coming up with a simulation base on the concept of biomass.Would pe pretty close to how fish behave in the ocean.


There is a total ammount of mass in the environment, in the form of free food, or living food (fish).Every time step, a fish can eat a minimum of 1 unit of mass to survive and grow 1 mass, or not eat and die, but on death their biomass becomes available as food.No spontaneous deaths, but fish can also eat fish half their size or less.


Possible outcomes: all biomass gathers up in one fish that grows big enough to eat the competition and dies off - Extinction.Or maybe, life finds a way, and some weird balance is met

I mean, I know there really wasn't a trait for rapid adaptability to changing environmental parameters put in there, but there isn't one for humans, either! I suppose an argument could be made that intelligence is equivalent to adaptability, but nevertheless, that simple experiment shows how misleadingly delicate and balanced an ecological system is. Simply put, evolution works slowly. A catastrophic event might wipe us clean! Biological forms are a slow sculpture, and they are just far too well-fit to their present environments to quickly deal with radical changes. That is, at least not while resources are anywhere near the carrying capacity. Now consider us- who use our technological crutches to artificially increase our environment's CC: what would a rapid change to such a system do? Don't answer; that was rhetorical.

One thing this video doesn't address is behavior. For example, how do creatures prioritize getting food over escaping from predators? They also need to return to the edge to survive, so after getting 1 food, do they take the risk to look for 2 or go home, how is that decided? Would getting even more food create more offspring perhaps?

Another issue is that all creatures seem to eat the same amount of food, and this doesn't affect their energy level. A better simulation would be to assign energy values to food pellets, and have thresholds for survival and reproduction at the end of the day. That way, bigger or faster creatures would actually need to eat more to succeed, but their traits might allow them to get more food. So you can evolve different survival strategies, like going for a high or low metabolism.

In your opinion, is evolution still even happening on humans in our modern society? I'm asking because we made ourselves quite independent from nature. Rarely anyone in a civilized culture will freeze to death in winter, nobody has to hunt and need any speed, strength or intelligence to get food. There isn't very much concurrence with wild animals (depending on the country you live in) that could have a notable influence on evolution. "Weak" people, unintelligent people, disabled people - no matter who - are usually helped by society and reproduce themselves just as often as others. Some characteristics I know of may make you less accepted by society, but rarely any characteristics (except diseases) I know of will make it more likely for you to die.

Of course there are exceptions, for example Malaria immunities on people in african countries (if I remember this correctly). The only other thing I could think of would be finding a partner, hormones and instincts will still play a big role. Yet, there's more to it (intellectual things) than when an animal tries to find a partner which probably makes natural selection have less influence.
I kinda feel like we almost cut ourselves off from that change, or at least slowed it down quite a bit.

Evolutionary biology reveals the sad state of life and humanity, and how all organisms are enslaved to the fundamental rules of the universe. Competition always arises in an environment of finite resources, because genes prioritize maximizing reproduction (since the ones that don't die out, leaving the ones that do. Even genes are enslaved to these logical rules), and so even when starting with a small population with plentiful resources that could easily be shared by all with no hunger and poverty, the population will naturally grow up to the point were the resources won't manage to be enough for everyone. And so poverty, hunger, competition, war and all sorts of other terrible things begin.

The only way I see of fixing this is severely editing our genetic material to remove the genes that pre-programmed us to prioritize reproduction, and then scan the population for rogue mutations that could f*ck it up. And that would leave us a lot more vulnerable to extinction.

I think this guy was very, very wrong about one thing. Let me explain:

If I can run 1 unit of distance per unit of time per unit of energy, then my ratio is (1/1)/1= 1. But If I could run twice as fast but use up twice the energy, then my ratio would be (2/1)/2 = 1. The ratio of speed to energy doesn't change, so that means that traveling faster does not punish me in any way. In fact, it means I can get my food before other people do. So it's not surprising, then, that the simulated population tended towards blobs who are faster. In real life, running faster probably does not increase energy consumption by an equal amount. That would imply perfect efficiency, which does not exist in nature. Instead, it would make more sense that energy consumption increases more than speed, which would then mean that faster blobs are less efficient and that increasing speed would be very risky in a low food environment, which is pretty counter intuitive. Then, by extension, slower blobs are more energy efficient and can make longer trips, which means that they would actually outlive faster blobs in a low food environment.

The biggest problem with simulations like this is that it is hard to draw conclusions form a single run as randomness can make anything happen in natural selection. You would normally have to re-run the simulation thousands of times to get a P < 0.05 value statistically.

The reason why the Efficients die is *because the Speeders kill them*.
Let me explain:
The thing is, that all creatures will start at the edge of the map, so theres only one way to go - into the middle where the food is.
Now, everytime a Speeder will start the day next to a Efficient, the Speeder will take all the closest foods and the Efficient will walk nowhere and waste energy because he cant sense any food around.

The history of where the creatures are when there is a change is also important because the current state of the blobs changes the elements of competition that will be favored. Since you moved from a higher population to a lower one, not only is the competion to find food more fierce, but the competition to not BE food is much more fierce. This is one reason why higher speed could be expected, and smaller bodies would take over more quickly as well since the larger preditors are missing out on meals as the ones focusing energy on speed over size leave them behind. You have to think more in terms of statecraft than engineering, since evolution doesn't have a mastermind or designer to turn back to the drawing board. If you set the same ending conditions from different starting points I think we can in many circumstances expect different endpoints. 'Endpoint', of course, meaning the state of equilibrium before another change occurs, not the end or high point.

At the end, when you had 10 creatures left, they were fast for different reasons that you think (at I least I believe so).
The creatures were competing with one less food every day for the past 90 days, and thus there was always going to be 1-3 extinct creatures. This is why they were fast at the end.
If you continued the simulation for let's say another 40 days (just a random number) with the food staying constant at 10, I think the creatures would have slowly became slower.
Of course, I'm not 100% sure, as I may be missing something, but I was hoping you'd do that to check if that's the reasoning.

The reason sense is not valued as high as it should be. Is because the area you're testing on is quite small. It doesn't help you if you know that there's something X distance away from you when it's going to be snatched up by the other creature taking it beforehand. Therefore the sense is going to be "capped" in efficiency to how much energy it takes and the distance it's likely to "snag" something up with the help out of. In other words, anything that appears in the immediate surrounding.
Additionally, the reason speed got valued higher with the food reduction is because you need to get to the food, before the other creatures with sense gets to them.

I think that you can take this simulation one step further. A good many years ago I saw a documentary on birds, can't think of which birds they were, but there were 3 classifications of behavior that I found interesting. The first was that a bird would preen everyone else (your helping gene, preens everyone even if they don't reciprocate), the second was one that would only preen itself (the selfish one, he would let others preen him but not return the favor) and a third that would hold a grudge (he would remember which birds did not reciprocate preening and would not ever preen them again). This was important for survival because, whereas, a bird could self-preen they could not get the back of their heads and neck leaving them open for parasites that could kill them. I would love to see this simulation done with that extra variable for the grudge-holders as the narrator called them in the documentary.

It would be interesting to see how adjusting your energy functions would affect the creatures. I don't think scaling their energy functions with the cube of size is very physical because in reality, many creatures that are much larger use energy more efficiently. Metabolism increases with volume as something like M ~ V^(3/4) https://royalsocietypublishing.org/doi/abs/10.1098/rspb.2008.0118
Obviously, this isn't a law like physical laws and there are exceptions, but in a group of related species this tends to hold pretty true and the constant changes from cohort to cohort. I think your velocity scaling is probably closer to reality. But it would be interesting to see if this change might yield bimodal population distribution. Also, is the simulation code and visualization software available somewhere?

7:52 What I find nice with this simulation, is that it shows how most extinction events occur and how populations can adapt through natural selection to almost any modification in their environment given enough time to adapt, generation after generation. This is precisely why humans are such a threat to biodiversity, it's because the changes we apply to the environment are too important and done in a too small amount of time for the most specialised species. That's also why usually the first species to disappear are the ones that are the most specialised and the ones that manage to stay around us and survive are the ones with the most adaptability like crows, rats and foxes. Paradoxically, and sadly, those are the species humans usually hate and want dead when, really, they should be admired.

I’d have to disagree and say there is such a thing as a more evolved species, in two interpretations.
One: one that has had greater/more changes. Numerically further from its original mean/average than other creatures.
Two: one that can adapt quicker than other creatures due to the way it has evolved.
Three: the likely combination of the above.

interesting video! I have a question: You state that there is no such thing as a "more evolved" creature. So wouldn´t you say the human is currently "outside" of normal evolution. Since the human can survive in many different enviroments while not evolving because humans have an ability to influence or change the enviroment. My point is: if one creature doesn´t need to evolve to adapt to different enviroments isn´t it a "more evolved" creature since it isn´t impacted by changing enviroments and thus will not die out so easily if there is a sudden change (eg sudden food shortening).


 There is also another point i disagree with the state that there are no "more evolved" creatures. Since it is possible for a creature that does everything better that another creature without a downside. In your simulation that is not possible, since every advancement has a hardcoded cost in it. But if (by natural selection) a creature evolved with for example a better mechanism for its legs that would cost less energy than the previous used one I would consider it a "more evolved" creature since it is both faster and consumes less energy.


A third thind i wondered is the size mechanism: You said if one blob is at least 20% bigger than the other one it can eat it. Wouldn´t that mean there is no perfect creature for that enviroment, since there will be an infinite size-changing to avoid the 20% "breakpoint" you artificially created?



Your simulation is helpful to some extend but of course very one dimensional. So i don´t think we can draw many comclusions to actual evolution.

Despite Darwin's own precaution of explicitly mentioning this, people still completely misunderstand natural selection. It is NOT survival of the fittest! It's not the strongest, the fastest or even the smartest creatures who survive. The species that survive are simply those who are most adaptable to change! No trait is better or worse than another in the real world which is far more complex and ever changing. The ability to adapt to change is itself a trait that should be included in a simulation. The experiment at 1:30 which showed that populations grow and then stabilise does not match reality. The Calhoun mouse utopia or Christmas Island(?) Reindeer catastrophe demonstrated that populations don't stabilise, they do the opposite: they boom and then die out.

Any kind of population stability is only attained through the presence of predators, disease and other forms of population control. Any population left on its own without something to keep its numbers down will eventually go extinct.

All these comments about "life is a simulation" got me worked up. The definition of a simulation is the imitation of a situation or process. Which means there would have to be another real universe from which this is simulated from. The likelihood that the original universe has developed the ability to simulate an entire infinitely large universe over an infinite amount of time, is not nearly as likely that we are just the original universe. In fact it's most likely impossible as this would require an infinite energy source, accessible by a life form in the other universe who then was able to create a machine that could simulate all of our reality indefinitely, meaning the source life form (which is likely maintaining the machine for the simulation) would have to survive for the duration of the simulation at the very least, for it to be useful to them and if you would suggest that the simulation is sped up, remember again that this would have gone on for an indefinite period of time so the speed at which this universe is simulated wouldn't actually change the fact that it would never end. There's too many impossibilities.

What about traits that may be seemingly disadvantageous? Such as how resistant a creature is to sickness. It would be obvious to have a good resistance to sickness, but let's say that all creatures got inflicted, and 50% of the creatures with higher resistance decided to collect food that day, instead of staying in shelter, resulting in 1% of them dying, because despite being more resistant to the sickness, it was still sick, and it ultimately meant it performed worse than a healthy creature. Do this over a bunch of generations, and we have a selection of creatures who can handle the sickness, but they tend to stay home when afflicted, because all those who didn't, gradually died off.

I have a bit of a problem with this on a metaphysical level as a species is made up of individuals, it's the individual organisms that actually exist, not "the species". "The species" is merely a concept that describes (categorizes) some number of individual organisms. How can a species change over time without, or not because of, the individuals changing over time? Is it not the individuals that change over time, that evolve, thus the species, the group, changes over time, evolves?
Maybe it's a difference between scientific nomenclature and philosophical nomenclature but it kinda seems like, conceptually, metaphysically/fundamentally, it can't be true that only a group changes over time and not the individuals that make up that group.

Natural selection is devolution not evolution. An organism cannot evolve without added information/energy/genetic code, if all the information is contained within a creatures DNA for say height, speed, ect; Then what your describing is variation within a kind not evolution, if say long hair is better in cold then short hair is more likely to die off this hasnt caused evolution just a variation is highly favorable.

A mutation is a loss of genetic information that causes a favorable outcome for instance lactose intolerance is the default and the loss of the genetic code to produce a specific enzyme that interacts with the lactate causes an individual to handle milk without adverse reactions. In this case information was lost i.e an enzyme but a benifit was gained i.e can drink milk past childhood.

Cancer another type of mutation is where a stem cell within the body loses the genetic code that controls its growth/cell division causing it to malfunction causing the cell to grow out of control where normally the sell would grow and then stop once its required function was met

So both size and speed reflect the species population... the faster the species the less of that species exist, the larger the specie the less of that species exist.  Could this be why the cheetah is so small in population? The issue with speed is that sure getting a mutation that grants higher speed will give the species an advantage and cause a population boom as the speedier genes allow the species to exploit the environment of which they exist...but eventually what they eat will die off or evolve ways to outrun or to evade them. If they manage to eat every member of the species they eat...they will soon face a population collapse. If the species they eat manages to gain equal speed they would require even more speed to catch their food.... requiring more energy resulting in  population collapse.

You need just enough sense to see food before another creature sees that food and just enough speed to get to it before another. Predators cannot really hide from prey, or predator for that matter, and migration isn't available so they have to chase. Chasing costs too much in the scenarios presented, meat gives no bonus energy, it takes too long to catch a runner and get to the edge, and so you will only loose over the days.

Important to point out that this barely scratches the surface of how evolution works in the real world. A few important things that are missing (a few of which I'm not sure how you'd simulate tbh):
-Separations due to climate, geography, active seasons, etc
-Sexual reproduction & speciation due to reproductive barriers
-Predator/prey "arms races"
-Sexual selection (the other, weirder arms race).
-Dominant/recessive traits
-Epigenetics (change in gene expression in response to environment, e.g., grasshoppers/locusts)
-Offspring care & associated costs/benefits
-Kin selection
-Dimorphism, sexual and otherwise
-Neutral drift - in reality, most mutations have no immediate effect, and do not experience selection pressure, but may form a framework for later adaptations. This turns out to be incredibly important!

Some of these concepts are deeply intertwined - just adding sexual reproduction and the possibility for genes being present but "switched off" would cover a lot of bases.

6:40 With the current rule set, speed is essentially a competition based trait. With a population of one, the lower the speed the better because one can go further and time is not a constraint.
However when there is competition for food, what counts is to get to the food first for the lowest cost possible => being slightly faster than the rest of the population.
The population would naturally reach a cap where the distance they are able to travel is much smaller than the whole area effectively reducing their hunting grounds to an area around their starting point with fewer competitors.
That's why there is no optimized speed in a vacuum and we can't say the faster creatures are better. If the creatures from the fastest generation would suddenly compete against the sarter ones, they would struggle because the cost of their speed is much higher than needed to get the benefit.

That's probably why in the longer following experiment, once the creatures have settled on the other axes, they start increasing their speed.

Allow me to share some analysis of environment and results it produces.


1. I think reason for higher speed being optimal, is that plane is too small. For speed to be optimal, it should allow Blob to reach all realistically available food before others. In each simulation your high speed Blobs were able to wander for a long time around the plane, so I think bigger plane would give chance to your slower Blobs that can reach food in the centre by sheer patience.


2. You may have noticed this already, but being a predator is penalized twice, which is why being a predator is not popular among Blobs. It's penalized first by a very high energy usage and penalized second time by "safe zone" mechanic. If Blob is small and fast it can eat food and go back home before predators catch him, once in home he cannot be harmed until the end of simulation.


 This could be "fixed" in two ways - first is to disable safe zone, once Blob is full it avoids predators until it exhausts it's energy, then it sleeps for the rest of simulation. Predators could eat sleeping Blobs unless they are too big for them. The other way is to allow predators to cooperate. First predator to touch another Blob only slows him down, second predator kills him and both of them get two portions of food from this. This would mean that predators would slowly exchange their size for numbers. There is also an option for predators to be able to eat dead Blobs from previous round (who died, because haven't found food) for one portion of food.

News flash... Survival of the fittest and evolution are not the same thing.

Mutations are almost AWAYS negative. Positive mutations are so rare, it is difficult to find any examples of them.

Survival of the fittest relies on inherent genetic diversity... the genetic code for various traits are within the parents genes... no mutations are required to have diverse offspring.

Dogs, for example, can be bred to be big or small, long hair or short, floppy ears or small ears... but you are not going to breed a dog to have wings.... The code for wings just isn't there.

Breeding is an artificial form of survival of the fittest and not evolution. No new data is added to the dog's genes only the traits that are not desired are bred out.

The purer the breed, the less diverse it's genes are. They become more specialised and less able to adapt to changes in their environment. They also tend to suffer from ailments that are characteristic of their breed because they no longer have the diversity required to correct the problem.

Survival of the fittest is a demonstrable fact... Evolution is a theory with virtually no supporting evidence.

Don't confuse or equate the two !!!

You said a couple of times, being fast is less efficient, because it costs you more energy. However, the energy cost scales linearly with the speed, so if you are twice as fast you need twice as much energy. It's not less efficient. The efficiency is the same. The relation between your output (speed) and your input (energy ) is constant for all blobs.

Well done and we should see more simulation on this topic. Sadly, the assumptions here are flawed...the incremental benefit arising from on genetic mutation would be very small - certainly nowhere near a 2x mean improvement (speed). Also, that mutation would only apply to ONE individual in a small starting population. My sense is that if these corrections are applied then, yes, you will see natural selection working but only after many, many generations. If you think about evolution of Neanderthal to Modern Human you only have 50,000 generations and I’ve never seen a simulation where such a change could be achieved solely through natural selection where each mutation is caused by a random event. Finally, as you get closer to the destination species so the random mutations  needed become very precise and increasingly complex.

What I found interesting was that at times during the food reduction simulation, you could see two separate clusters develop on the graph. Could this perhaps simulate a branch in evolution where two species exist from a common ancestor but eventually one line dies out?

I'd love to see a simulation like this that included such things as predation options (bumping smaller critters instead of eating them, costs more energy but offers more energy chance to eat other critters), Stealth options, poison options, and a dynamic food environment, for each food uneaten it flips a coin, "tails" and it returns, "heads" and it returns and a new food returns. If no food remains at the end of each day, the food gets reduced during the next day by 5% (or by 1 food, whichever is larger).

My expectation is variations and some few extremes. Something that is fast and strong and a predator can eat the others and is faster. A small and but poisonous critter can still perhaps get to the food but cannot be eaten because it is poisonous (for simplicity sake, poisonous critters cannot be eaten rather than killing the predator that tries to eat it).

finally, editing the map, instead of returning to the edge, make the map circular, and create "nests" (starting/ending points) along a smaller circle roughly 1/2-2/3 of the radius of the map's radius. Instead of returning to the edge of the map, the critters need to return to their specific nest. Critters will also have the option between days to move their nest along the nest-circle, to get them further away from predators or other competitors.

Faster creatures covered more ground initially when the probability of finding food was highest.

The run on 6:21 is also interesting to notice board position. To the right, creatures became faster and, to the left, larger. That kind of spacial division happens in nature where there are natural barriers and usually leads to specialization. the reason that speed was "king" in the last simulation is rather easily explained: its due to two factors: time, and covered ground. time is simple: the day has a given amount of time, and in that time you have to locate food, move towards it, and make it back to the edge. with 10 food that spawns randomly it can be that you have no food in your vacinity, which means more time searching for food and more time traveling to the food and back to the edge. if this time exceeds the day time limit, the creature dies. the only two values that matter for this are speed and sense. but no matter the sense, with too little speed it still dies if the creature takes longer than a day to get to the food and back, even if it takes the shortest route thanks to the sense skill

the second part is competition: there was not enough food. even if another creature had great sensing, if every piece of food is already sensed by a faster creature, the high sense/low speed creature is gonna die out, because knowing the position of every piece of food is worthless if its already taken by the time the creature could reach it
so speed wins again

now to the size problem: with the shrinking population count, size was never a useful factor. even if you can start out surviving by eating other individuals, due to the food shortage and the therefore caused low population every "carnivorous" (large) creature is bound to either run out of prey in its vicinity or not be able to catch up due to the preys speed.

so all in all a very predictable outcome in your last run. the environment was in no way ideal for carnivores.

But a few side notes: A large creature not necessarily needs a lot of food. A small creature however does not necessarily need very little. Would a human have the need of food scaled up from a mouse, we would certainly die out as we would need a ton of food... An hour without and we would die. This works the other way around, too, like if we scale down Elephants...

Also, you set up your virtual environment with a fixed amount of food and space. Yet while evolution has a ton of space and even more possibilities of food (you could diverse in carnivores and herbivores).

Also, slow moving creatures can sometimes live on without food for a huge amount of time and generally get really old, too. A slow metabolism like the Greenland shark has can very much be a huge advantage.

This is a completely unrealistic model of evolution.

1) 99.9% of mutations are harmful or fatal. (Remine, The Biotic Message, page 221.)
This makes it mathematically unscientific to assume that mutation is a mechanism behind evolution.

2) Tortoises, sloths, and other slow animals are still alive and thriving in many untouched parts of the world. They make up a vital part of the ecosystem, and "natural selection" or mutation are not proven to make them evolve into something different or die out. A quick search and you can discover the importance of thousands of slow animals.

But It's a cute video, nice and sciencey, but not of actual reality.

Hi I have one remark on your methods. Statistically you can't prove normality if the population size is low (<200). In addition, small population sizes in evolution don't allow for the tail-ends of the bell-curve to exist to a high-enough count, which is likely why your whole population died at 7:47 . Although you never talk about distributions per se, in 2:39 you specifically show various distributions incl a bimodal distribution. I suggest whenever doing these simulations that your population size is at least 1000 to overcome these hurdles and be able to clearly show distributions

It's important to note that these are mathematical models that does not necessarily reflect reality in any meaningful way. This is why you have to rely on empirical evidence (evidence that you can experience) when dealing with science, instead of theoretical evidence, like in the above video.

I know this is not a scientific debate on evolution, but i want to say that this is evidence for micro evolution, but it is hard to transfer this simulation to macro evolution / darwinism. Since natural selection needs positive traits, there needs to be a steady supply of positive traits. You programmed such traits, like speed and size, thus showing that there is a need for a designer to feed natural selection with new traits. Yes the traits are randomly picked, but the "solution space" was implemented by a person.

I might be wrong, but I dont think so.

I created a program where creatures in a 2D world compete with each other for food. Each cell on the map has a color, and each creature has 3 traits, R, G, and B. Whoever is closest to the color in the map square wins that square and lives to the next round. The survivors also have one slightly mutated offspring, one cell over. Sometimes the kid is closer to the current map color, sometimes its not. The fittest survive. But they also migrate, and different squares have different colors, and they must adapt to the new colors as they march across the map.


I put a starting population on a Salvador Dali image, and after a few thousand generations, the population turned into living art. Check it out on my channel, if you're interested.

That’s a good point about evolution not necessarily leading to more advanced or “human-like” creatures all the time. This is why Chimps and other primates are still around even though we humans like to see ourselves as the “most advanced.” Humans have big brains and upright gaits, but Chimps and most other primates are still better at living in jungles and climbing around in trees. One crazy thing about natural selection is that it doesn't work towards perfection, it works towards, well, what works! In an AP Biology class you'll hear the question "why do that, when it could do this, this being more efficient" and the answer is that although you are correct in how it would be more efficient, it didn't happen and what we have now is just what worked when it was needed, and therefore was passed to future generations. Truly a fascinating phenomenon within natural selection and evolution!

You also forgot that growing smaler is an option to save energy.

8:25 "Efficiency" means "I do not need this reliabiltiy anymore". In this case, reliabiltiy was "reliably getting the food".
If you need a certain sense to find the food and a certain speed to get there first, it is not a mater of efficiency. Speed is a survival trait as much as sense is.

It is worth noting that a too forgiving environment actually hinders evolution. Just think of all those times were birds that lived on a island without predators, literally lost the ability to fly. Flight is the one defining trait of "birds". Everything about their build is optimized for that. Yet they lost that ability, because they no longer needed it for survival.
And then humanity placed a predator there, and they died out quickly. Like the Dodo. Or this one: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=jXcY0-UC8tM
Why do you sound like OverSimplified?

It's a very interesting visualization. But I believe it's too oversimplified to draw any conclusions from. You basically have to create a much less harsh environment, where death is determined by a moving average of amount eaten not just insta death if you didn't eat last night. This is probably more representative of single celled organism or something like that, but not general at all. Also you can't just initialize all of them at the same initial states. Because you're introducing fierce competition in a small space. It might be more interesting to initialize randomly, for example. Finally, it would probably be better if the environment was also larger to allow different speed/size creatures move freely.

I get that this is just a quick exercise and it's a great one for little computational expense, but just thought i'd give my point of view.
Thanks again for sharing.

At 3:11 you said the faster creatures were less efficient, but I don't think that is true. The faster creatures are not less efficient because they can cover the same distance with the same energy. In the real world x2 speed required >x2 energy.

Great video, I love it! Just one small comment: you mention at 6:34 that it's surprising that the average speed went down because we didn't explicitly change the way speed works. One thing that I feel could be expanded more is the individual economy of a blob. It seems to me that your simulations given enough time might end up with blobs that have the best of all traits. Or if it doesn't it's because there is too even of cost benefit to make a change like the 2x speed is also 2x energy, in which case the population might tend towards pure randomness. A creature can't be the biggest, fastest, and have the most sense, or whatever other traits, because it would take a diet much larger diet to do so. This is the answer to questions creationist have like "after billions of years why don't humans have invincible skin and brains as big as a car and if trees compete for light by growing tall, why haven't they reached space yet?" Because an individual has to distribute it's limited energy to growing many different parts of it's body. Part of the reason dinosaurs died out is because they had enough food around them (and oxygen) to support a very large creature, but when this changed the total amount of resources an individual creature had to work with went down. And as you sort of mentioned how beneficial it is to work as a species as a group or alone effects total population size. Animals that go solo don't have to share with others and can there for be bigger, or stronger in other areas. I think it's more useful when food quantity stays constant.

I also think that creating formulas for traits or mutations that has a higher amount of variation or randomness would be interesting, because you might see two rival species form.

Very, very cool. Here are some ideas to try out that might make these models more representative of what we see in real life:
- don't reset the creatures energy each day. Instead, make them "inherit" the energy of their parent. This will greatly affect how important energy cost is, I'm sure
- waste heat as a product of energy expenditure. In real life, energy use actually goes DOWN as size increases! However, you risk overheating. Similarly, the smaller the life form, the higher the risk of being too cold (this is especially true for warmblooded animals)
